title: 114_hr3594
content: The "Federal Perkins Loan Program Extension Act of 2015" extends the authority to make loans to undergraduate students in need at institutions of higher education. Through September 30, 2017, institutions of higher education can make loans under the Federal Perkins Loan Program to eligible undergraduate students with no outstanding balance on previous loans, as long as all Federal Direct Loans have been awarded. Institutions of higher education can make loans under the Federal Perkins Loan Program to eligible undergraduate students with outstanding balances on previous loans, as long as all Federal Direct Loans have been awarded. Additionally, eligible graduate students who received a loan prior to October 1, 2015, can continue receiving loans for academic programs until September 30, 2016. Institutions of higher education can continue making loans under the Federal Perkins Loan Program from the student loan fund to enable students to complete academic programs. However, after September 30, 2017, no additional loans can be made under this program. No funds are authorized for appropriations after fiscal year 2015. Eligible graduate borrowers who received loans before October 1, 2015, can still receive disbursements under part E of the Higher Education Act of 1965. Institutions can continue issuing loans under the Federal Perkins Loan Program until September 30, 2017. No new loans can be made after this date. Eligible graduate borrowers who received loans before October 1, 2015, can still receive disbursements under the Higher Education Act of 1965. Additionally, amendments have been made to the distribution of assets from student loan funds, with changes effective starting October 1, 2017. Section 463A(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require disclosure prior to disbursement, with specific changes to paragraphs 12 and 13. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to require disclosure prior to disbursement of loans under this part, including notices and explanations about loan availability, repayment benefits, consolidation options, interest rate comparisons, and borrowing limits. The borrower has reached the maximum annual borrowing limit for Federal Direct Stafford Loans as referenced under section 455(a)(2)(A).
